content:
I made a mistake (imagine that!) :sweat_smile:

I said that the first-order calculus can be summarized by the commuting diagram

image.png

That is wrong. Instead, we need two separate commuting diagrams

20201218_213822.jpg
It seemed natural to me to try to combine things but if I put the two diagrams together and claim the whole thing is commutative, then I force some things to be isomorphisms that aren't isomorphisms.

I think I found a way to extend this to Ω~2\tilde\Omega^2Ω~2 via

20201219_012348.jpg

The literature, e.g. here, says Ω~2=Ω~1⊗AΩ~1\tilde\Omega^2 = \tilde\Omega^1\otimes_A\tilde\Omega^1Ω~2=Ω~1⊗A​Ω~1, but I am not sure if that is correct :thinking:

I think Ω~2\tilde\Omega^2Ω~2 is a sub-bimodule of Ω~1⊗AΩ~1.\tilde\Omega^1\otimes_A\tilde\Omega^1.Ω~1⊗A​Ω~1.

The map μ1:A⊗KA⊗KA→A⊗KA\mu_1:A\otimes_K A\otimes_K A\to A\otimes_K Aμ1​:A⊗K​A⊗K​A→A⊗K​A is a bimodule morphism that acts on basis elements by "popping out the middle", i.e.

ei⊗Kej⊗Kek↦ei⊗Keke^i\otimes_K e^j\otimes_K e^k \mapsto e^i\otimes_K e^kei⊗K​ej⊗K​ek↦ei⊗K​ek

and extends linearly to all of A⊗K3,A^{\otimes_K 3},A⊗K​3, i.e.

μ1(α)=∑i,j,kα(i,j,k)μ1(ei⊗Kej⊗Kek)=∑i,k[∑jα(i,j,k)]ei⊗Kek.\mu_1(\alpha) = \sum_{i,j,k} \alpha(i,j,k) \mu_1(e^i\otimes_K e^j\otimes_K e^k) = \sum_{i,k} \left[\sum_j \alpha(i,j,k)\right] e^i\otimes_K e^k.μ1​(α)=∑i,j,k​α(i,j,k)μ1​(ei⊗K​ej⊗K​ek)=∑i,k​[∑j​α(i,j,k)]ei⊗K​ek.

If f,g∈Af,g\in Af,g∈A, then clearly

μ1(f α g)=f μ1(α) g.\mu_1(f\,\alpha\, g) = f\,\mu_1(\alpha)\, g.μ1​(fαg)=fμ1​(α)g.

I think Ω~2\tilde\Omega^2Ω~2 should be the kernel of μ1∘m:Ω~1⊗AΩ1→A⊗KA.\mu_1\circ m: \tilde\Omega^1\otimes_A\Omega^1\to A\otimes_K A.μ1​∘m:Ω~1⊗A​Ω1→A⊗K​A.

Let α,β∈Ω~1\alpha,\beta\in\tilde\Omega^1α,β∈Ω~1 so that

α⊗Aβ=∑(i,j)∑(k,l)α(i,j)β(k,l)(ei⊗Kej)⊗A(ek⊗Kel)=∑(i,j)∑(k,l)α(i,j)β(k,l)δj,k(ei⊗Kej)⊗A(ej⊗Kel)=∑(i,j,k)α(i,j)β(j,k)(ei⊗Kej)⊗A(ej⊗Kek),\begin{aligned} \alpha\otimes_A\beta &= \sum_{(i,j)}\sum_{(k,l)} \alpha(i,j) \beta(k,l) (e^i\otimes_K e^j) \otimes_A (e^k\otimes_K e^l) \\ &= \sum_{(i,j)}\sum_{(k,l)} \alpha(i,j) \beta(k,l) \delta^{j,k} (e^i\otimes_K e^j) \otimes_A (e^j\otimes_K e^l) \\ &= \sum_{(i,j,k)} \alpha(i,j) \beta(j,k) (e^i\otimes_K e^j) \otimes_A (e^j\otimes_K e^k), \end{aligned}α⊗A​β​=(i,j)∑​(k,l)∑​α(i,j)β(k,l)(ei⊗K​ej)⊗A​(ek⊗K​el)=(i,j)∑​(k,l)∑​α(i,j)β(k,l)δj,k(ei⊗K​ej)⊗A​(ej⊗K​el)=(i,j,k)∑​α(i,j)β(j,k)(ei⊗K​ej)⊗A​(ej⊗K​ek),​

where (i,j,k)(i,j,k)(i,j,k) is a length two path i→j→ki\to j\to ki→j→k and

m(α⊗Aβ)=∑(i,j,k)α(i,j)β(j,k)ei⊗Kej⊗Kek.m\left(\alpha\otimes_A\beta\right)= \sum_{(i,j,k)} \alpha(i,j) \beta(j,k) e^i\otimes_K e^j \otimes_K e^k.m(α⊗A​β)=∑(i,j,k)​α(i,j)β(j,k)ei⊗K​ej⊗K​ek.

so that

μ1∘m(α⊗Aβ)=∑(i,−,k)[∑jα(i,j)β(j,k)]ei⊗Kek.\mu_1\circ m\left(\alpha\otimes_A\beta\right)= \sum_{(i,-,k)} \left[\sum_j \alpha(i,j) \beta(j,k)\right] e^i\otimes_K e^k.μ1​∘m(α⊗A​β)=∑(i,−,k)​[∑j​α(i,j)β(j,k)]ei⊗K​ek.

This is zero when

∑jα(i,j)β(j,k)=0.\sum_j \alpha(i,j) \beta(j,k) = 0.∑j​α(i,j)β(j,k)=0.
